planet.name: Jupiter

generalInfo.description: Jupiter is the largest planet in the solar system and the fifth planet from the Sun. It is a gas giant composed mostly of hydrogen and helium, with no solid surface and a massive, swirling atmosphere.
generalInfo.namesake: Jupiter is named after the king of the Roman gods, reflecting its massive size and prominence.
generalInfo.age: Jupiter has been known since ancient times and is one of the brightest objects in the night sky.

potentialForLife.description: Jupiter's harsh conditions, including intense radiation, extreme temperatures, and lack of a solid surface, make it unlikely to support life as we know it.
potentialForLife.climateChangeImpact: Jupiter's atmosphere and dynamics are unaffected by external factors, serving as a natural laboratory for understanding planetary weather systems.

sizeAndDistance.rank: Largest planet in the solar system

orbitAndRotation.leapYearExplanation: Jupiter does not experience leap years, as its orbital period is much longer than Earth's.
orbitAndRotation.seasonalEffects: Jupiter's minimal axial tilt results in very little seasonal variation.

moons.description: Jupiter has 95 known moons, including the four largest, known as the Galilean moons: Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto.
moons.origin: Some moons are thought to have formed with Jupiter, while others are captured objects from the solar system.
moons.averageDistance: Varies widely; Ganymede orbits at about 665,000 miles (1.07 million kilometers).
moons.rankInSize: Ganymede is the largest moon in the solar system.

planet.rings: Jupiter has a faint ring system composed of dust particles ejected from its moons.

formation.description: Jupiter formed about 4.5 billion years ago from the gas and dust left over after the Sun formed. It was the first planet to form in the solar system.

layers.name: Core
layers.description: A dense core of rock, metal, and hydrogen compounds.

layers.name: Mantle
layers.description: A thick layer of metallic hydrogen surrounding the core.

layers.name: Atmosphere
layers.description: An outer layer of hydrogen and helium gases with trace amounts of methane, ammonia, and water vapor.

surface.features: Jupiter has no solid surface, but its atmosphere is marked by features such as the Great Red Spot, a massive storm that has lasted for centuries.
surface.oceanCoverage: Jupiter has no oceans, though it may have a layer of liquid hydrogen beneath its atmosphere.
surface.volcanicActivity: Jupiter itself has no volcanic activity, but its moon Io is the most volcanically active body in the solar system.

composition.other: Trace amounts of methane, ammonia, water vapor, and other gases

atmosphere.protection: The thick atmosphere provides no protection from the intense radiation and high winds present on Jupiter.

magnetosphere.cause: Generated by electric currents in Jupiter's metallic hydrogen layer.
magnetosphere.effects: Jupiter's magnetic field is the strongest of any planet, creating intense radiation belts and auroras.
magnetosphere.polarityReversal: Jupiter's magnetic field is stable and does not undergo polarity reversals like Earth's.
